contact.header: Take action if you think a person may be disqualified from renting
contact.intro:
If you have reasonable cause to believe that a person is disqualified from renting, you can request a Notice of Letting to a Disqualified Person (‘a Notice’) from the Home Office to confirm this. You can then use this to help you end the tenancy.

To request a Notice, please call the landlord's helpline and we'll arrange a time to call you back to collect the information we need.
contact.subtitle: Landlord's helpline

required-info.intro: For the callback you will need the following information:
items: the name(s) of the person(s) you'd like to request a Notice for
your role (if you are a landlord or an agent authorised to act on behalf of the landlord)

useful-info.intro: If you have any of the following information, it would also be useful:
items: date of birth of your tenant or occupier
nationality of your tenant or occupier
Home Office reference number for your tenant or occupier

reference-number.summary: What's a Home Office reference number?
reference-number.details: If the person has applied for a visa with the Home Office, they will be issued with a reference number. This could be an application or appeal number, an Application Registration Card (ARC) number or a case ID number.

landlord.intro: If you're the landlord we will need to know:
items: your company name (if you have one)

agent.intro: If you're an agent acting on behalf of the landlord we will need to know:

what-next.content: Following the call, we'll review your request and will contact you within 10 working days. In the unlikely event that you have not heard from us after this time, please call us again on the landlord's helpline as detailed above.
